repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body: There's an extra `stdint.h` include in `digraph.c` but modifying that file affects the Vim 5 digraph comments.

comment_data.body: unless this is required for things directly in pos.h, in general we don't want to have "mega-headers" that bring in other headers (`os.h` is an exception).
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1,6 +1,9 @@
 #ifndef NVIM_POS_H
 #define NVIM_POS_H
 
+// for INT_MAX, LONG_MAX et al.
+#include <limits.h>

comment_data.body: what's the reason for this? ZyX made it an enum intentionally.
It's used directly below it. Do you prefer moving the `MAXCOL`, `MAXLNUM` to another header to avoid an `#include`?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1,6 +1,9 @@
 #ifndef NVIM_POS_H
 #define NVIM_POS_H
 
+// for INT_MAX, LONG_MAX et al.
+#include <limits.h>

comment_data.body: Consistency with MAXLNUM. `enum` is restricted to `int` values.
No, but maybe worth mentioning in the commit message.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1,6 +1,9 @@
 #ifndef NVIM_POS_H
 #define NVIM_POS_H
 
+// for INT_MAX, LONG_MAX et al.
+#include <limits.h>

comment_data.body: `LONG_MAX` is in the patch description. Do you mean to mention that a new header is included in some file?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1,6 +1,9 @@
 #ifndef NVIM_POS_H
 #define NVIM_POS_H
 
+// for INT_MAX, LONG_MAX et al.
+#include <limits.h>

comment_data.body:
This breaks buffer updates.

Tried changing this line to `const long MAXLNUM = LONG_MAX;` but it fails the static assertions where `SIZE_MAX >= MAXLNUM`.

Can buffer updates be done in chunks of `SIZE_MAX`?

comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1,6 +1,9 @@
 #ifndef NVIM_POS_H
 #define NVIM_POS_H
 
+// for INT_MAX, LONG_MAX et al.
+#include <limits.h>

comment_data.body:
So I started looking at this, but I'm confused on an early level. First, the assertions are justified because of the following casts, good we have them :)

But then, if `SIZE_MAX < MAXLNUM`, that means we're potentially having more lines than fit in a `size_t`. Is that a real usecase, can that happen? I'm on shaky ground here, but I always assumed `SIZE_MAX` is really the largest addressable thing. The vim issue doesn't really discuss things...

I'd have figured `#define MAXLUM SIZE_MAX` would be the way to go then. Since line numbers are `long`, things get complicated, but could we just take the smaller value of `LONG_MAX` and `SIZE_MAX`?

We've always left the question open on chunking updates, and I'm a tad unclear on how it could be done.

> But then, if `SIZE_MAX < MAXLNUM`, that means we're potentially having more lines than fit in a `size_t`. Is that a real usecase, can that happen?

No, it can't happen. (and that's why we have the `SIZE_MAX >= MAXLNUM` static assertions.)

We could simply "truncate" the buffer update and mention it in a log message `ELOG()` or `WLOG()`).  Then we don't have to solve "chunking" right now to move forward with this.
